description.narrative:
Detta beslut avser konsultstöd för specifik uppföljning av jämställdhet, jämlikhet och rättighetsperspektivet i Världsbankens reproduktiv-, mödra och barnhälsa projekt (Uganda Reproductive, Maternal and Child Health Services Improvement Project) 2017-2021.
Med anledning av identifierade svagheter kopplat till rättighetsperspektivet, jämställdhet och jämlikhet, planerar ambassaden avropa en konsult under Sidas ramavtal för global hälsa/SRHR. Konsulten kommer att arbeta tillsammans med Världsbanken och hälsoministeriet med huvudsakligt fokus på uppföljning av integrering av jämställdhet, jämlikhet och rättighetsperspektivet.
Konsulten kommer att delta i de uppföljningsresor som leds av Världsbanken två gånger per år, och förväntas ge rekommendationer och stöd till Världsbanken och ministeriet kring hur implementering av projektet kan förbättras vad gäller jämställdhet, jämlikhet samt rättighetsperspektivet. Konsulten förväntas också bidra till att upptäcka och rapportera om eventuella oegentligheter/generella brister i implementeringen av projektet.
Support to consultant for follow up of gender equality, equity and the rights perspective in World Banks reproductive, maternal and child health project 2017-2021

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: As the decision on contribution was prepared in the previous version of Trac (before the upgrading in March 2018) the objectives of the intervention are not shown above. This contribution focus on support for consultancy services aimed at integrating gender, a Human Rights Based Approach (HRBA) for health and adolescent health (ADH) in the Sida-supported World Bank project: Uganda Reproductive Maternal and Child Health Services Improvement Project (URMCHIP). The consultancy services have been provided by Royal Tropical Institute in Amsterdam (KIT), during a one year time period from August 2017 to August 2018. The consultant, who is an expert in gender, HRBA and SRHR has undertaken two missions to Uganda, one in September 2017 and one in April 2018. During the first mission, the consultant participated as a team member in the World Bank's monitoring mission, providing recommendations on gender, HRBA and ADH in discussions with the Ministry of Health (MoH) and the World Bank. Together with the Embassy programme officer, the Bank and MoH, the consultant also undertook a field visit to Rwenzori region to study a similar RBF programme, supported by Enabel, to learn from their implementation. During the second mission the consultant was accompanied by an RBF-expert at KIT. Together, the two consultants visited a health facility to be enrolled in the project, held discussions with various technical staff at MoH and facilitated a one-day long workshop to further discuss HRBA, gender and adolescent health and what kind of actions could be taken to improve the integration of these three areas. Both the Bank, the MoH and the Embassy participated in the workshop. The final report report has provided in-depth recommendations on how the integration of gender equality/equity, HRBA and adolescent health could be further improved under the three main components of the project. The MoH, the World Bank and the Swedish Embassy have had extensive discussions around which recommendations to take on in the project. However, whereas many of the recommendations provided by the consultant are very relevant, it is not yet clear to what extent they will be adopted by the MoH and the Bank in the actual project implementation.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
